user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtAssertEx:
```c
bool UtAssertEx(bool Expression, UtAssert_CaseType_t CaseType, const char *File, uint32 Line, const char *MessageFormat,
                ...)
{
    va_list va;
    char    FinalMessage[256];
    uint32  TestSegmentCount;
    uint32  TotalTestCases;

    UT_BSP_Lock();

    ++UT_SegmentCounters.TotalTestCases;

    if (Expression)
    {
        CaseType = UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS;
    }

    if ((uint32)CaseType < UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MAX)
    {
        ++UT_SegmentCounters.CaseCount[(uint32)CaseType];
    }

    TestSegmentCount = 1 + UT_TotalCounters.TestSegmentCount;
    TotalTestCases   = UT_SegmentCounters.TotalTestCases;

    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    va_start(va, MessageFormat);
    vsnprintf(FinalMessage, sizeof(FinalMessage), MessageFormat, va);
    va_end(va);

    UtAssert_DoReport(File, Line, TestSegmentCount, TotalTestCases, CaseType, CurrentSegment, FinalMessage);

    return Expression;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtAssertEx:
void UT_BSP_Lock(void)
{
    OS_BSP_Lock_Impl();
}
...
void OS_BSP_Lock_Impl(void)
{
    int status;

    status = pthread_mutex_lock(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_lock: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * Temporarily Disable/Defer thread cancellation.
         * Note that OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl() calls write() which is a cancellation point.
         * So if this calling task is canceled, it risks leaving the BSP locked.
         */
        pthread_setcancelstate(PTHREAD_CANCEL_DISABLE, &OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessCancelState);
    }
}
...
void UT_BSP_Unlock(void)
{
    OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl();
}
...
void OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl(void)
{
    int status;

    status = pthread_mutex_unlock(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_unlock: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    else
    {
        /* Restore previous cancellability state */
        pthread_setcancelstate(OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessCancelState, NULL);
    }
}
...
void UtAssert_DoReport(const char *File, uint32 LineNum, uint32 SegmentNum, uint32 TestSeq, uint8 MessageType,
                       const char *SubsysName, const char *ShortDesc)
{
    uint32      FileLen;
    const char *BasePtr;
    char        ReportBuffer[320];

    FileLen = strlen(File);
    BasePtr = File + FileLen;
    while (FileLen > 0)
    {
        --BasePtr;
        --FileLen;
        if (*BasePtr == '/' || *BasePtr == '\\')
        {
            ++BasePtr;
            break;
        }
    }

    snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer), "%02u.%03u %s:%u - %s", (unsigned int)SegmentNum,
             (unsigned int)TestSeq, BasePtr, (unsigned int)LineNum, ShortDesc);

    UT_BSP_DoText(MessageType, ReportBuffer);
}
...
void UT_BSP_DoText(uint8 MessageType, const char *OutputMessage)
{
    char   Buffer[16];
    size_t MsgLen;
    uint32 TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL;
    uint32 MsgEnabled   = BSP_UT_Global.CurrVerbosity >> MessageType;

    if (MsgEnabled & 1)
    {
        UT_BSP_Lock();

        /* Determine if the message type warrants special treatment (color/highlight/etc). */
        switch (MessageType)
        {
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MIR:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_WARN:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_GREEN;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_BLUE;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_BEGIN:
                OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl("\n", 1); /* add a bit of extra whitespace between tests */
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_GREEN;
                break;
            default:
                break;
        }

        if (MsgEnabled <= 1)
        {
            TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL;
        }

        snprintf(Buffer, sizeof(Buffer), "[%5s]", UtAssert_GetCaseTypeAbbrev(MessageType));

        if (TermModeBits != OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(TermModeBits);
        }

        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(Buffer, strlen(Buffer));

        if (TermModeBits != OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL);
        }

        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(" ", 1);
        MsgLen = strlen(OutputMessage);
        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(OutputMessage, MsgLen);
        if (MsgLen == 0 || OutputMessage[MsgLen - 1] != '\n')
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl("\n", 1);
        }

        UT_BSP_Unlock();
    }

    /*
     * If any ABORT (major failure) message is thrown,
     * then call a BSP-provided routine to stop the test and possibly dump a core
     */
    if (MessageType == UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT)
    {
        OS_BSP_Shutdown_Impl();
    }
}
...
UtAssert_TestCounter_t UT_SegmentCounters = {0}
...
UtAssert_TestCounter_t UT_TotalCounters   = {0}
...
static char            CurrentSegment[64]
...
typedef enum
{
    UTASSERT_CASETYPE_NONE,    /**< Reserved value, No messages should be used with this */
    UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT,   /**< Test sequence abort (major failure, cannot continue) */
    UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE, /**< Test case failure status messages */
    UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF,     /**< Test Setup Failure (TSF) status messages */
    UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF,     /**< Test Teardown Failure (TTF) status messages */
    UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MIR,     /**< Manual Inspection Required (MIR) status messages */
    UTASSERT_CASETYPE_WARN,    /**< Test was unable to run (WARN) status messages (e.g. initial condition wrong) */
    UTASSERT_CASETYPE_NA,      /**< Test Not Applicable (NA) status messages */
    UTASSERT_CASETYPE_BEGIN,   /**< Beginning of test status messages */
    UTASSERT_CASETYPE_END,     /**< End of test status messages */
    UTASSERT_CASETYPE_INFO,    /**< All other informational status messages */
    UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS,    /**< Test case passed (normal) status messages */
    UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FLOW,    /**< Other condition checks/messages that record test flow, but are not assertions */
    UTASSERT_CASETYPE_DEBUG,   /**< Debugging messages */
    UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MAX      /**< Reserved value, No messages should be used with this */
} UtAssert_CaseType_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
UtAssert_DoReport(File, Line, TestSegmentCount, TotalTestCases, CaseType, CurrentSegment, FinalMessage);

    return Expression;
explanation:
I selected fragments that may lead to unreachable code or make other code unreachable at runtime and therefore should be investigated for compliance with MISRA C Rule 2.1. In particular, the call to OS_BSP_Shutdown_Impl() (inside UT_BSP_DoText) is potentially non-returning (e.g. calls exit/abort/terminate). If it does not return, any code after the point where UT_BSP_DoText is invoked (for example the return in UtAssertEx) would be effectively unreachable in that execution path. Therefore both the shutdown call and the caller's subsequent return deserve review.

I also included the pthread lock/unlock implementations because they manipulate thread cancellation state and the comments explicitly mention that OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl() is a cancellation point. If a thread is canceled at an I/O cancellation point while the BSP is locked, code paths that assume the lock was released (or that cancellation state was restored) may never be reached; this can create code that is conditionally unreachable or leave subsequent code paths non-executable in practice. Those lock/unlock branches should be inspected to ensure there are no guaranteed-or-accidental non-returning/canceling behaviors that would create unreachable code.

All other code fragments in the provided functions were not flagged because they are syntactically reachable and not obviously made unreachable by the provided control flow. For example, the switch cases in UT_BSP_DoText are reachable depending on MessageType and MsgEnabled; the loop in UtAssert_DoReport terminates normally; the va_list usage in UtAssertEx is correctly bracketed with va_start/va_end. If further code (not provided) shows that OS_BSP_Shutdown_Impl or the BSP console output functions are non-returning or otherwise alter control flow (longjmp, terminate, thread cancellation without cleanup), additional fragments would be suspicious and should be reported.
